abstract: Chinalco is set to walk away from its planned investment in Rio Tinto, The Financial Times reported, citing unnamed sources. An announcement is expected at 8 p.m. G.M.T.
snippet: Chinalco is set to walk away from its planned investment in Rio Tinto, The Financial Times reported, citing unnamed sources. An announcement is expected at 8 p.m. G.M.T.
lead_paragraph: Update | 8:01 a.m. Chinalco is set to walk away from its planned investment in Rio Tinto, The Financial Times reported, citing unnamed sources. An announcement is expected at 8 p.m. G.M.T. More here.

headline.main: Chinalco May Be Set to Walk Away From Rio Tinto Deal

abstract: China’s proposed $19.5 billion investment in Rio Tinto, the Australian mining giant, could be scrapped this week, ending this country’s bid to gain a larger stake in one of the world’s biggest resource companies.
snippet: China’s proposed $19.5 billion investment in Rio Tinto, the Australian mining giant, could be scrapped this week, ending this country’s bid to gain a larger stake in one of the world’s biggest resource companies.
lead_paragraph: Update | 1:15 p.m. China’s proposed $19.5 billion investment in Rio Tinto, the Australian mining giant, could be scrapped this week, ending this country’s bid to gain a larger stake in one of the world’s biggest resource companies, The New York Times’s David Barboza reported Thursday, citing a person briefed on the talks.

headline.main: Rio Tinto Considers Ending China Deal

abstract: The Chinese government’s largest ever investment in a Western company, a proposed $19.5 billion stake in the mining giant Rio Tinto Group, collapsed early Friday.
snippet: The Chinese government’s largest ever investment in a Western company, a proposed $19.5 billion stake in the mining giant Rio Tinto Group, collapsed early Friday.
lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI  The Chinese government’s largest investment ever in a Western company, a proposed $19.5 billion stake in the Australian-British mining giant Rio Tinto Group, collapsed early Friday, dealing a blow both to China’s global corporate ambitions and to its efforts to gain clout in the natural resources market.

headline.print_headline: Western Mining Giant Ends Plan to Sell $19.5 Billion Stake to Chinese Company

byline.original: By David Barboza and Michael Wines
